headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: October Jobs Report; Bobby Flay is Interviewed about Restaurants; LSU and Alabama Face Off. Aired 8:30-9a ET

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: All right. So, the October jobs report just out. We're going to gather the numbers, make sense of them, bring them to you in just a minute.Let's get some context, though, with our whole team who is here. Chief business correspondent Christine Romans is with us, business correspondent Rahel Solomon. So, Christine, this is the -- we've been saying all morning, they want a goldilocks.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTINE ROMANS, CNN CHIEF BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: They want a positive number but not too much because we've got to grapple with this inflation.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Right.So we have 261,000 net new jobs added in the period, which is a little - I think a little hotter than people thought.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That's hot. Yes.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: I mean, and in normal times, that would be a lot of jobs created. And 3.7 percent is the unemployment rate. So it went up a little bit, but still near that, you know, 50-year low. So, this is one of those stories - I guess that you could say that is maybe a little goldilocks. The unemployment rate getting a little bit hotter. That's what the Fed wants to see. but you still had a lot of jobs created in the period. And I'm going to dig in here and find out where we added those jobs.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: We'll come back to Christine because she's actually doing -

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: OK. Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, trying to get the information right now.Rahel, hello to you.

utterances.speaker: RAHEL SOLOMON, CNN BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Hi, guys.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, look, it's coming -- it's a very critical time politically and for the country because people are going to be deciding who their leaders are. and the White House, as you know, they are a little bit nervous about this. I think everyone is a little bit nervous.

utterances.speaker: SOLOMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean, look, it's a critically time politically, it's a critical time economically. So this is a number that we've all be watching to see. Are we going to start to see the labor mark cool off? And I would argue this is a sign of that, right, 261,000 as Christine pointed out.We'll have to look at the revisions that we got for the last few months. But to put that in perspective, that would be roughly the lightest number we've seen in quite some time, right? So, we knew that this was coming as the Fed started raising rates in March and has continued to raise rates, of course, since then as they make borrowing more expensive. So we all knew -- Christine and I have talked about quite a bit that at some point the labor would slow, we've just been waiting to see when it would happen.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And so what's the Federal Reserve's response to this, do you think?

utterances.speaker: SOLOMON
utterances.sentences: You know, I'd have to look at wages, I'd have to look at labor force participation, but this is a slowing, which the Fed wants to see. It wants to see a cooldown, a moderation. It doesn't want to see job growth plummet.So, I would say that this is perhaps a step in the right direction. But also going to be looking at labor force participation. It's also going to be looking at wages for sure.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: There's an unemployment rate. You can see how much it's fallen since the really worst days of the pandemic.One thing here, manufacturing jobs added there, 32,000. That's interesting to see here. And Rahel was talking about how it's a slowdown. And 261,000 would be hot any other - you know, any other time you'd be like, that's so many jobs. But we - on average, about 420,000 jobs on average every month this year. So, this is below the year's pace. But this has been -- so now we're talking about 4 million jobs have been created this year in the U.S. economy. That is way more than you normally see. Usually, you just have 2 million jobs in a - 2 million or 3 million a year. We've already really been far above that.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Is this goldilocks?

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: I don't know. I mean, it's so hard to say what's happening in the job market when you look under the hood because we have so many jobs that are still open. The Fed needs to see the job market cool down a little bit so it doesn't start to spin off other inflation and get inflation intrenched.Do you think it's goldilocks, Rahel?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And goldilocks is not too fast, not too slow, right?

utterances.speaker: SOLOMON
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, I'm trying to remember the op-ed that the president wrote. I believe it was in "The Wall Street Journal" earlier this year where goldilocks was sort of 150 to 200. Now, that's just sort of off the top of my head but I believe -

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: One hundred and fifty is what the White House had put out.

utterances.speaker: SOLOMON
utterances.sentences: Right, I believe that was the figure. So, are we there yet? No. Are we sort of getting closer to the 400,000 that we added earlier this year, the 500,000 jobs that we added earlier this year in January? Yes, we're moving in the right direction. Are we exactly there?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You know what's so interesting, all of these headlines, like above the fold in the papers today, Amazon.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SOLOMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: They're stopping - you know, basically pausing a lot of their corporate hiring.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Like, after hiring like crazy.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: No, I hear you but, I mean, I - I am seeing -- we are seeing -- listening to these CEOs saying, we're going to take a beat. Look at the lift also. Twitter is a different animal why they're doing the layoffs.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But these companies are responding to something.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: So you can see the cracks for sure. But I was talking to an economist earlier today who said, you know, it's not fair to say that there are - that there's real weakness in the job market. You have to look hard to find the exception, which is the weakness in the job market. It's still very, very strong. But, you're right, looking ahead, these CEOs are saying --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That's their job to lock ahead.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: But I want to ask you about something that Karine Jean- Pierre, the press secretary at the White House, said just right before this jobs report came out.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Sure.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Does it surprise you that the White House is not preparing for a recession?

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Well, look, the worse -- something worse is happening right now, 8.2 percent inflation.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: That's what they're really worried about. And they're spinning in circles trying to figure out -- to do everything they can. They don't have a lot of leverage to do for the inflation.I mean, I think the people who are calling for a recession are still calling for a relatively mild and shallow recession. Even Larry Summers has said, oh, and, by the way, if we get a recession, it won't be very bad. And entrenched inflation is way worse than anything else.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I know they say this. I think - look, parsing words here, she said they're not having meetings. I mean that's -- it doesn't mean that they're not preparing for a recession. I think they are well aware of what the headwinds are and what's happening here.

utterances.speaker: SOLOMON
utterances.sentences: And also, I mean, I think -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: But let me just get this - and say I think - what we have been saying, what I'm hearing from everyone here, right, from all of you, business experts, is that coming out of Covid we don't really have the metrics to measure this new economy.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Exactly. Exactly. Covid broke the charts.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: It broke the charts. And so now we sit here. We're trying to figure out what it means.When I ask economists and CEOs, finish this sentence, the economy is x.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Weird.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: They say confusing.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That's my word (ph).

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Chaotic, hard to read. You know, they don't really know exactly.

utterances.speaker: SOLOMON
utterances.sentences: I think it was Jason Furman (ph), an economist, who said recently, if you're not a little confused about the economy, you're not paving attention.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SOLOMON
utterances.sentences: And that's true, right, because think about what the pandemic did. It created a lot more savings. So even though inflation is still at 8.2 percent, people are still spending because they have a cushion, right? So, the pandemic did really strange things, not just in terms of our checking accounts and our balance sheets, but also supply chains. So, there are a lot of sort of strange things happening that wouldn't normally happen and they're happening, by the way, all at once.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Four days - four days from the midterms and we are talking about the number one issue by a mile, Christine, on voter's minds.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Right. Right. Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: SOLOMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Can I also just say -

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: And when they go to the grocery store, the bills are higher. Gas - the gas - price the gas tank. The gas station gets way too much attention I think because a lot of people, you know, hybrid commuting, fewer commutes. Like, there's all these different reasons why you could say on paper people could be feeling a little better this time than they did in 2008 when we were also worried about a recession. People feel lousy about the economy. Seventy-five percent of people we polled say we're already in a recession, you know. So, the way people feel, then that becomes real.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SOLOMON
utterances.sentences: Just bouncing off that. I know we talked about what the White House is and isn't preparing for. If you're at home and you're hearing these recession warnings and you can prepare, you want to prepare.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes. Good advice.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I think one of the smartest things we heard this morning was from Frank Luntz, where he said it's not necessarily about inflation or the jobs, it's about affordability.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SOLOMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That's the issue.And, look, it's weird, you're right, we have low unemployment but yet people can't find jobs. It's just - it's so odd.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: We've never seen anything like it.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you both.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you both.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Great. Great. Great. Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: SOLOMON
utterances.sentences: Good to be with you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Just -- you just heard the details from the latest jobs report. Who better to talk about that than Bobby Flay himself, who employs more than 250 people in the restaurant business, really hit hard by Covid. He is our guest visiting barista this morning. Bobby Flay will join us. Stay here.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Here is the breaking news that I'm getting in right now. Bobby Flay is going down, down, down!(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Oh my God.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: We were just talking about the October jobs report. One industry that continues to face dire staffing shortages, that's restaurants. Competition for workers remain intense - it remains intense. About two-thirds of restaurants say that they are understaffed. That's according to an industry survey. And then there's the soaring food prices, supply chains, log jams and so on and so forth.So, joining us now, the man who knows what it takes to run a restaurant, chef, restaurateur, entrepreneur, and I would say personal friend of mine, Bobby Flay. His new show "Beat Bobby Flay: Holiday Throwdown" premieres Tuesday on The Food Network and Discovery Plus. I can't wait for Bobby Flay to invite all three of us on this program.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOBBY FLAY, CHEF, RESTAURANTEUR, FOOD NETWORK PERSONALITY
utterances.sentences: No problem. Love to have you. LEMON

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: Good to see you too.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: As you're watching the jobs reports, is it -- does anything resonate with you in - as far as staffing and all that?

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: What does?

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: I mean the thing about restaurants is, it's a - it's a - it's an every night focus group of how people are feeling about the economy.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: You know, and what's happening is, it's getting squeezed from every sort of corner and edge. I mean labor's expensive, commodities, meaning, you know, the cost of goods, foods, et cetera, is expensive. And, of course, occupancy costs is always expensive. The landlords never look out for you. I mean they're always - you know, they have very deep pockets and they're -

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Trying to squeeze you.

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: And they're not going to - they don't -- they don't take the pressure off.On the or side of it, I think the consumers are feeling the pressure as well because they turn on the TV, they walk - they look at social media and they understand that, you know, we're on the brink of some really bad economy here. And so people, they tighten their wallet.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Do you think that, we're on the brink of a pretty bad economy?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Well, they say - you're saying they say we are, and so that effects people, right?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: What do you think?

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: I do.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You do?

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean, listen, unfortunately, I've been around long enough to see this happen before.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: And, ultimately, we're able to come out of it, but you do have to hold on tight. But I feel like something not good is happening. I mean you look at all the report and I watch what people are -- the way people are acting in the restaurants. It's a really good --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Meaning? Meaning? FLAY

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So interesting.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes. And what does that look like? Are you able to find people? Because I've heard this is a big issue of everyone that was left go by restaurants at the height of the pandemic, now they're having difficulty hiring good people back.

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: Well, we all said -- and I say "we" meaning the -- my friends in the business, where is everybody? Like, you thought like, you know, the pandemic hit and everybody would be willing to come back to work right away, but that did not happen. We basically, you know, opened the doors and wondered where everybody was. And now people are starting to trickle back, but, again, it's very -- very, very competitive.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And, you're right, listen, Bobby and I both live out on Long Island. And you know Eric Lemonides. He owns Almond out in Bridgehampton.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I love that restaurant.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: But people are having to provide housing for -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Employees.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: For employees because, you know, it's - it's tough. Like, there are incentives. You're having to pay people bonuses and help -

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: Bonuses, benefits, anything to make people feel like, you know, this is the place I want to work. And also like, you know, the problem is, if somebody comes by and offers your employee an extra dollar an hour, you know, that adds up over the week and over the year. And so they - they'll consider that. So you have to do certain things that are not just about the actual dollar itself to make people feel like they want to stay in your restaurant or on your (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: What can the people who make laws and the people in the - the financial experts, what can they learn from the restaurant industry as it comes to this new economy? What can you teach them? And what are they missing?

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: Well, I can tell you one thing, the person - the people that are going to be paying for this is the consumers. Restaurant are going to have to keep charging more money to survive so that they can actually create jobs. I mean - and also survive as a proprietor as well. I mean it's a vicious cycle at this point and it's unfortunate.I say that we're literally a generation away of people understanding what it really costs to go eat in a restaurant and be OK with it. Meaning, all of us, we all pay or own bills. We go to the restaurants. We know that chicken costs $24 at our favorite restaurant. What about if I told you it's going to be $38 next week? Right.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Might not go (ph).

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: That's your reaction. So my - so somebody who's 16 years old right now, who's not paying their bills yet, they're going to - they're going to feel comfortable paying that because that's what they - that's what they see and that's what they know.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: We're not ready to do that.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All of this is really important but we have something more important, which is when Don Lemon was on your show.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, geez.

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: Oh, that's right.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Can we play it?

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: This was the highlight of "Beatdown."(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: That's right, when life gives you Don Lemon, you make lemonade, baby.I watch you all the time.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You do?

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And are you cooking or are you just chilling?

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: No, I'm usually at home. You have this thing where you're like, if somebody says something that you just take a moment and you just go, ah, we'll be right back. I mean you don't even have to say what you're thinking.

utterances.speaker: ALEX GUARNASCHELLI
utterances.sentences: Can I remind you there's someone else here who's like that?

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: Me?

utterances.speaker: GUARNASCHELLI
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: What did Don Lemon cook and was it good?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I love her.

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: No, Don didn't - Don didn't cook, he just tried to get me beat. That's his role.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I did. I caused him to lose his (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: Yes, he did. Yes, exactly.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Because you - his burger wasn't as - well, and that was Alex (ph) -

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: Alex Guarnaschelli.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Alex Guarnaschelli. I saw Alex the other night at Alba in the city.

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I try to -- I try to - listen, I try to support local restaurants.

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: I love that.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Somehow Don has figured out a way to go out to dinner on this schedule. Kaitlan and I are still working on that.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Bobby, do you know for eight and a half years I did not really get to go out and have a proper dinner because I had a show on at 10

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: And it's going to get more expensive, Don.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It's expensive. It's expensive.

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: That's the lesson of the day.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, but she's right, I mean she held up a mirror to you. And - but I think you were also holding up a mirror to the people who are in charge of us about - no, I mean, in charge of the economy and what have you about what is to come and how -- what should be done about it.

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, it's -- listen, I -- we'll get through this.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. FLAY

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: How do they feel?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: How do they feel?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: How they feel. Exactly (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you, friend.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Bobby, we've got to - we've got to kick you out of a gig again. You're out of here. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: OK, I'm gone.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Bobby, thank you. It's so good to see you.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Thanks for joining us.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It's really great to see you.

utterances.speaker: FLAY
utterances.sentences: Congratulations to all three of you. This is fantastic.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you very much. I wish we would have to talk about Rotel versus, you know, queso, because it's really important.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We'll come on the challenge. Queso. Well, just save that for the next -

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: We'll bring you back.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: It's coming. It's coming.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Bobby's new show, "Beat Bobby FlayHere we go.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I love how the control room's like making me read this tease. Like I have some investment in Don's LSU Tigers taking on Kaitlan's Alabama Crimson Tide this weekend. Who will win and, more importantly, which anchor will earn bragging rights?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, that's your fight song. Why am I doing that?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: That's Alabama's fight song you're dancing to.OK, I think I've already won. Like, we can just end the throwdown.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, an SEC showdown. Alabama and LSU will battle it out tomorrow in one of the biggest college football games this season.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Can I - and can I -

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: For the record, I told Don to take the sunglasses off. People in the Midwest are like turning off their TVs right now.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Just the sunglasses?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Well, this is what we did at LSU to try to hid that we had been drinking for the game.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well, we never drink. We run on (INAUDIBLE) during the game.All right, the rivalry this morning clearly is real. Don was dancing to the Alabama fight song earlier. Obviously Alabama and LSU are playing on Saturday if you did not understand why Don has had an outfit change during the break. The question, of course, is who is going to win. I have paid our senior data reporter Harry Enten with this morning's number to say Alabama.

utterances.speaker: HARRY ENTEN, CNN SENIOR DATA REPORTER
utterances.sentences: I got my -- I'm wearing my Columbia Lions jersey. I -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Is that for me?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, boy.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: You have to stop wearing that.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Is that for me?

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: That's not - that's for you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, boy. That's not - Harry, that's not a thing.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: That -- that is a thing.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That is for me.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It's not a thing.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, boy.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Yes, I -- I left my --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Here we go.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Did he play?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Who's going to win? Give us the data.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But he's a great guy.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: I left my athletic days behind back in elementary school, I'll just say that. All right.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Oh, I like our chances.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: The -- Kaitlan likes this. Not a big surprise. Chance of winning Saturday's matchup, Alabama at 69 percent, LSU at 31 percent. So, hey, Don has a little bit of a shot here but Kaitlan is the clear favorite.Let's give you a little history on Alabama versus LSU all time. Alabama all time the clear leader with 55 wins, LSU with 26 wins. Five ties back in the day where you could get that in college football. You can't get that anymore since, I believe, 1996. But let's take a look at the chance of winning the national title because that's, of course, what we're all interested in at the end of the day. You'll notice Ohio State, 27 percent, Georgia, 22 percent. They're actually taking on Tennessee this weekend in another big SEC matchup, 11 percent. Alabama at 10 percent. And I apologize to Don, but LSU has a less than 1 percent chance of winning the national title. It's math, Don, I don't necessarily control it. Finally, college football fandom by region. Poppy, of course, is from that Midwest. There are more in the Midwest than anywhere else at 41 percent.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: The south, Don and Kaitlan, at 40 percent. No one on this crew is from the west, but I will say, Neil Sedaka, my uncle, his current residence is, in fact, in the west in California and Harry, of course, from the northeast, just 25 percent. But I love my Columbia football Lions.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank the Lord for you representing me. I'm just going to stay out of this.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It's not - its not the same, though, Kaitlan, is it?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Can I say -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I mean, the SEC, it's like the - it's the - COLLINS

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Doesn't compare.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: The SEC is a different world.I will say, I don't even think our biggest competitor this weekend is really LSU. It's our own unforced errors that Alabama has had. They have not been amazing on the road yet, but I think that they're ready for this. We had a bye week last week.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Can you tell people, because we hope he's watching, (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: This is a signed photo of Nick Saban that may or may not sit in my office and Zach may or may not have furiously run down to get.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And this is, by the way, if you can't -- this is just LSU. This sits in my office.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It feels like college game day where Lee Corso (ph) makes his pick and he puts on the head of the mascot of whoever he picks. And you should be like putting on that LSU Tiger head right now.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Here's the thing. I know I look crazy but this is actually how I dress if I go to an LSU game, on the rare occasion that I -- because I don't have a chance to go as much as I used to. But here's a - here the thing, Kaitlan and I were supposed to go down to Death Valley, to Baton Rouge, and go to the game.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Next week is going to be so crazy when it comes to the midterm elections we've decided - like, we don't need -- we had a lot this week. We didn't need that on our plates. And, plus, I did not want her being harassed and to feel bad at Death Valley at tailgating in the stadium when we win and she loses.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Oh, please. I am a really sore loser, I will say, but I have full confidence. And also, when you're emotionally invested, as I am, it's sometimes better to just watch it from your house.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Your neighbors don't care if you're yelling at the TV.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, around the bowl, down the hole, roll Tide roll.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Are you going to take the sunglasses off to say good-bye to people?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Harry. Thanks, everybody. I appreciate it.CNN "NEWSROOM" starts right after the break. Have a great weekend, everyone.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And roll Tide.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Go, Tigers.
